1.0   ACCIDENTAL PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

1.1      City of Pittsfield - Cleveland Chlorinator. Policy on Safety, Accident Prevention and Emergency Response

The City of Pittsfield is committed to full compliance and adherence with all applicable laws and regulations regarding environmental protection, worker safety, accident prevention and emergency response.  To advance this policy, the City of Pittsfield:

?    Seeks opportunities to achieve continuous improvement of safely performance.

?    Periodically reviews operations to confirm compliance and adherence with safety requirements and identify opportunities, as are technically and economically feasible, that will reduce risk.

?    Responds to community interests and concerns about the actual and potential impact of our operations on safety and the environment.

?    Designs, builds, and maintains facilities in conformity with governmental regulations and to ensure that they can be operated in an environmentally sound and safe manner so as to minimize the risk of exposure to employees and the public at large to hazardous materials. 

?    Provides safety training and enforces safety and security policies.

?    Establishes programs and systems to identify and abate potential hazards in the workplace, educate employees about hazards, and train employees on how to prevent accidental releases and associated hazards.

?    Coordinates safety and emergency response program with local community emergency response officials. 

?    Ensures that environmental and safety policies are effectively communicated.

?    Establishes programs and systems to facilitate compliance with this policy by employees as well as contractors.

?    The facility's response to emergencies includes the following aspects:  

    Personnel notification and reporting responsibilities; 

    Emergency notification required by government regulation and policy;  

    Drills that include notification and reporting coordinated with local agencies;

    Current phone numbers required for internal and off-site notifications; and 

    Training program for emergency response team members. 





1.2    Risk Management System

The implementation and management responsibilities for the Plan must be clearly defined.  The City of Pittsfield has developed a management system to implement and maintain compliance with the RMP and emergency response programs.  This management system identifies lines of responsibility for the entire program and each of its key elements. Mr. Brian Stack, Water Superintendent, is responsible for the implementation of this Risk Management Plan and is identified throughout this document as the Risk Management Program Coordinator (RMPC).

Table 1 identifies the key staff positions that are responsible for the major RMP elements.

2.0  PROCESS AND SUBSTANCE SUBJECT TO 40 CFR PART 68

The City of Pittsfield owns and operates the Cleveland Chlorinator Facility located at 29 Old Windsor Road in Hinsdale Massachusetts. The purpose of the facility is to generate chlorinated solution which is used to disinfect the Pittsfield water supply.  The Cleveland Chlorinator Facility currently stores up to 6,000 pounds of chlorine in three one-ton containers. The chlorinator facility is a dedicated building less than one mile away from the water treatment plant which is located next to the Cleveland Reservoir. Since the Cleveland Chlorinator Facility stores more than 2,500 pounds of chlorine, the facility is required to comply with the re

quirements of 40 CFR Part 68.

Chorine is a listed regulated substance under both RMP and PSM.  Chlorine in its gaseous state has a greenish-yellow color and has a pungent irritating odor similar to bleach. Chlorine is neither explosive nor flammable, but as a strong oxidant supports combustion. Chlorine gas can react violently with greases, turpentine, ammonia, hydrocarbons, metal filings, and other flammable materials. Chlorine gas will not conduct electricity, but will be very corrosive to exposed electrical equipment. Dry chlorine gas will not corrode steel or other metals but is extremely corrosive to most metals in the presence of moisture. The compression of chlorine gas creates chlorine liquid. Liquid chlorine changes easily to a gas at room temperatures and pressures.  

The RMP regulation identifies three separate sets of requirements for process classified as Program 1, Program 2 or Program 3.  This facility is subject to the Program 3 Risk Management Program, comprised of the following five elements:

?    Management Program

?    Off-site Hazard Assessment

?    Accident Prevention Program

?    Emergency Response Program, and

?    Risk Management Plan.

3.0  OFF-SITE HAZARDS ASSESSMENT

RMP requires that two off-site hazard assessments be conducted, a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario.  The consequences of these releases are assessed by using mathematical models to estimate the distance to toxic or flammable endpoints specified in the regulation.  A circle centered at the modeled release with a radius equal to the endpoint distance is drawn on a map satellite photograph and the types of public receptors that are located within that circle are determined and reported in the Risk Management Plan.

At the Cleveland Chlorinator site, chlorine gas is

ario be explored.  An alternative release is assumed to occur during typical meteorological conditions specified as stability D (neutral) with 3 m/sec wind speed. An alternative scenario may include the worst-case scenario with any active or passive mitigation measures, an actual release event that has occurred in the operational history of the plant, or simply possible failures that could result in an accidental release.  The three alternative scenarios included:

?    Flashing Liquid Release;

?    Choked Vapor Release;

?    Chlorine Gas Vacuum Pipe Release.

The worst-case alternative release scenario is the Flashing Liquid Release which is estimated to have a release rate of 339 pounds/ minute for 3.24 minutes and results in an estimated distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.3 miles.

As shown in Figure 3, only adjacent commercial and industrial areas are within the Toxic Endpoint circle.

5.0   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Appendix O of the RMP document contains the Five Year History Log. The City of Pittsfield is required to report information related to any sudden release of chlorine from the storag

currently the only substance that is stored onsite in amounts greater than the regulated threshold.  Chlorine is contained as a liquefied gas in one-ton containers and utilized as a disinfecting agent at the facility.  In this analysis, an electronic tool called RMP*Comp was utilized to perform the off-site consequence analysis required under the RMP Rule. RMP*Comp makes the same calculations that you calculate manually by following the procedures described in EPA's guidance document. At the time of the analysis, the most current version was RMP*Comp 2.01.

The consequence of a chlorine release from a container is independent of the type of storage.  EPA's RMP Guidance provides the methods used to determine the release rates. Through chlorine-specific tables, the distance from each facility to the point at which a toxic concentration would be detected if a release occurred can then be estimated. 

In performing a worst-case scenario analysis, a ten-minute release under worst case meteorological conditions (F stability , 1.5 m/sec (3.4 mile/hr) wind speed and 25 ?C (77 ?F) ambient air temperature) were used.  These meteorological conditions can be thought of as a clear night and light wind, typical of early morning hours when the air is moderately still.  The worst-case scenario also assumes that all releases occur at ground level. 

After determining the release rate, the RMP Guidance reference table provided the distance to the toxic endpoint by utilizing the release rate and the topography of the area.  The RMP Guidance suggests that the closest value to the calculated value be used if the release rate values fall between two values.  The chlorine specific equation for rural topography from distance to toxic endpoint in miles (D) was determined from the reference table as 1.3 miles for the worst-case release scenario.  

In addition to investigating the worst-case scenario for an accidental release, a Risk Management Plan requires that an alternative release scen

e building that has resulted in one or more of the following consequences:

?    on-site or off-site personal injury, 

?    significant on-site damage or 

?    off-site emergency response.

The required information for the RMP accident history will be collected in accordance with incident investigation procedures established in Appendix L.  To date, no accidental releases have occurred at this facility.



6.0   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The purpose of the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) is to identify the planning and specific response actions to be taken during an emergency that would maintain the quantity and quality of water, protect employees, minimize disruption to the public, and preserve property.  This plan's objective is to ensure employee safety and health and on protection of the community from operations.  Prompt internal and external communications, emergency equipment, and trained personnel are the key ingredients of the ERP.

The ERP accomplishes the following: 

?    Defines the responsibilities of the Site Emergency Coordinators (SEC)

?    Establishes procedures for assessing scenarios to be handled by internal personnel and those that require the use of the local Emergency Response Team (ERT)

?    Establish procedures for internal and external notification and crisis communications, including emergency contact information.

?    Help the utility minimize the impact of an emergency on its facilities by developing general actions and procedures and providing critical response information.

?    Help the utility protect the health and safety of its employees, its customers, and the general public.

?    Provide training guidelines to develop and conduct emergency response training for utility staff.

?    Provide guidelines for distribution, revision, and updates of the ERP.

The Plan addresses the four phases of emergency management (preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation), and is intended to be used to augment existing Water Treatment Plant (WTP) ERP.



7.0   PLA

NNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The City of Pittsfield, under the RMP and PSM programs, has designed the chlorinator facility and organized its manageme?nt system to effectively address hazards and potential risks.  The operating procedures, emergency prepared?ness, and the operational elements of system maintenance, safe operating practices and ongoing personnel training are necessary to support a continual improvement in facility safety.  These programs are all documented so that needed information about the safe handling of all chemicals present at the facility is continuously available to employees. 

The City of Pittsfield is considering several changes to improve safety including:  the installation of an external emergency eye wash, the installation of beacons and horns both inside and outside the facility and is also assessing the replacement of the chlorine gas disinfection system with a sodium hypochlorite system.
